You were hereafter to be hailed as the benefactors
of your species; your names adored as belonging
to brave men who encountered death for honor,
and the benefit of mankind. And now behold!
with the first imagination of danger, or, if you
will, the first mighty and terrific trial of your
courage you you shrink away and are content
to be handed down as men who had not strength
enough to endure cold and peril, and so, poor
souls, they were chilly and returned to their warm
firesides. Y Why that requires not this preparation;
Ye need not have come thus far and dragged your
captain to the shame of a defeat t merely to
prove yourselves cowards. Oh! be men, or be more
than men. Be steady to your purposes, and firm
as rock; this ice is not made of such stuff as your
hearts might be; it is mutable, cannot with
stand you if you say that it shall not. Do
not return to your families with the stigma
of disgrace marked on your brows. Return as heroes
who have fought and conquered and who know
not what it is to turn their backs on the foe.
He spoke thus with a voice so modulated
to the different feelings expressed in his speech,
with an eye so full of lofty design and heroism,
that can you wonder that these men were
moved. They looked at one another and were
unable to reply. I spoke; I told them to retire
and consider of what had been said.

not lead them further north if they strenuously
desired the contrary; but that I hoped that
with reflection their courage would return.
They retired and I turned towards my friend but
sideration of these points and the well balanc

disturbed by the near approach of death. I dare
not ask you to do what I think right for I
may still be misled by passion.
That he should live, to be an instrument of
mischief disturbs me; in other respects this hour
when I momentarily expect my release is the only
happy one which I have enjoyed for several
years. The forms of the beloved dead flit
before me and I hasten to their arms.
Farewell, Walton. Seek happiness in tranquillity
and avoid ambition even if it be only the
apparently innocent one of distinguishing yourself
in science & discoveries. Yet why do I say this?
I have myself been blasted in these hopes,
yet another may succeed.
His voice became fainter as he spoke; &
at length exhausted by his effort he sunk
into silence. About half an hour afterwards
he attempted again to speak, but was unable
— he pressed my hand feebly and his eyes
closed forever while the irradiation of a gentle
smile past away from his lips.
Margaret, what comment can I make on the
untimely extinction of this glorious sprit? What
can I say that will make you understand
the depth of my sorrow? All that I should ex
press would be inadequate & feeble. My tears
flow- My life is overshadowed with a cloud
of dissappointment. But I journey towards
England, & I may there find consolation.
I am interrupted— what do these sounds
portend? It is midnight. The breeze blows
fairly; & the watch on deck scarcely stir—
Again there is a sound as of a human voice
but hoarser- it comes from the cabin where the
remains of Frankenstein still lie. I must
arise s & examine— Good night my sister- –
Great God! What a scene has just taken
place- I am yet dizzy with the remem
brance of it. I hardly know whether I
shall have the power to detail it; yet the
tale which I have recorded would be incomplete
without this final & wonderful catastrophe.
I entered the cabin where lay the remains of my
of my ill-fated, & admirable friend. Over him
hung a form which I cannot find words to
describe gigantic in stature, yet uncouth & distor
ted in its proportions. As he hung over the
coffin his face was hid by long locks of ragged
hair– but but one vast hand was extended,
in colour & apparent texture like that of a
mummy. When he heard the sound of my
approach; he ceased to utter exclamations of
grief & horror, & sprung towards the window.
Never did I behold a vision so horrible as his
face, of h such loathsome yet apalling hideous
ness. I shut my eyes involuntarily, as
recollecting what were my duties with respect
to this destroyer, I called on him to stay.
He paused – Looking on me with wonder, &
again turning towards the lifeless form of his
creator he seemed to forget to my presence;
whi and every feature & gesture seemed instigated

— That is also my victim

My pity ammounted to horror – I abhorred myself.
But when I discovered that he– the author of

that whilst he accumulated upon me wretchedness
& despair, he sought his own enjoyment in
feelings & passions from the indulgence of

bitter indignation filled me with an insatiable
thirst for vengeance. I recollected my threat
& resolved that it should be accomplished. I

was not miserable. I had cast off all feeling,
subdued all anguish to riot in the excess of
my despair. Evil thenceforth became my good.
Urged thus far I had no choice but to adapt
nature to an element which I had chosen willingly.
The completion of my demoniacal design thencefor

re-kindled within me. — Wretch, I said,
it is well that you come here to whine over
the desolation which you have made – you
throw a torch into a pile of buildings, &
when they are consumed you sit among the
ruins & lament the fall. Hypocritical
fiend! If he whom you lament still lived,
still would he be the object, again would he
become the prey of your accursed vengeance.
It is not pity that you feel– you lament
only because the victim of your malignity
is withdrawn from your power.——
Oh! it is not thus— not thus – interrupted

ticipated – But now, that virtue has become

turned into bitter & loath

ing despair, in what
should I seek for sympathy? I am contented
to suffer alone whilst my sufferings shall
endure. When I die, I am well satisfied
that abhorrence & opprobrium should load
my memory. Once my fancy was soothed with
dreams of virtue of fame & of enjoyment.
Once I falsely hoped to meet with beings
who pardoning my outward form would love me
for the eminent excellent qualities which I was so
eminently capable of bringing forth. I was
nourished with high thoughts of honour &
lf devotion. But now vice has degraded me
neath the meanest animal. No crimes no
mischief, no malignity no misery can be
found parallell with mine. When I call over
the frightful catalogue of my deeds I cannot
believe that I am he, whose thoughts were once
filled with sublime & transcendent visions of
the beauty & the majesty of goodness – But
it is even so – The fallen Angel becomes a
malignant devil – Yet even that enemy of
God & man had friends & associates in his
desolation. I am quite alone.
You, who call Frankenstein your friend, seem
to have a knowledge of my crimes & his
misfortunes. But in the detail which he
gave you of them he could not sum up the
hours & months of misery which I endured
wasting in impotent passions. For whilst I
destroyed his hopes, I did not satisfy my
own desires. They were forever ardent & craving.
Still I desired love & fellowship, & I was stil

Farewell, Frankenstein. If thou wert yet alive
& yet cherished a desire of revenge against me,
it would be better satiated in my life than my
destruction. But it was not so. You sought
my extinction because that I might not cause
greater wretchedness; & if yet by in some mode
unknown to me, you thou hast not ceased to think
& feel, you thou desirest not my life for my own
misery. Blasted as thou wert, my agony
was still superior to thine: for the bitter sting
of remorse may not cease to Rankle in my wounds,
until death shall close them forever.
But soon, he cried with sad & solemn enthusi

The light of that conflagration will fade away.
I know not My ashes will be swept into the sea
by the winds. My spirit will sleep in peace;
or if it thinks will surely not think thus.
Adieu.
He sprung from the cabin-window, as he said this,
upon an ice raft which lay close to the vessel;
he was soon borne away by the waves, & lost
in the darkness of distance.
